McCampbell, Jules Furthman, Leigh Brackett', 'Number of discs': '1'} I first saw this movie in the early 60s, when I was a young kid, and it stayed in my mind. It's that good. I recently saw it with my 11 year old son, and he just loved it; this boy normally won't watch westerns. It's that good.

John Wayne, Dean Martin, Walter Brennan all do a great job. Even Rick Nelson, not someone you'd expect to see in a western, does a solid job. Angie Dickinson is very likable. It all hangs together, and doesn't work too hard at it; just goes down nice and easy. (Ok, I mixed my metaphors, but you get the drift.)

What can I say, I love this movie! If you like the classic ones, buy it, it's worth every penny. if you like the classic westerns, this is a must-see, must-own District B13/District 13: Ultimatum 2-Pack Cyril Raffaelli (Actor), David Belle (Actor), Patrick Alessandrin (Director), Pierre Morel (Director) & 1 more Rated: R Format: Blu-ray Movies & TV, Blu-ray, Movies ["Includes: District B13 Paris, 2010. An isolation wall surrounds the ghetto cities of District B13. Within these walls, without effective law enforcement, gang rule is absolute. Damien is a member of an elite police squadron, highly trained in martial arts. He goes undercover to infiltrate a gang in order to defuse a neutron bomb and save District B13 from annihilation. Damien recruits the help of a criminal named Leito - whose only goal is to save his sister from the clutches of the same gang. District 13: Ultimatum Two years have passed since elite police officer Damien Tomasso (Cyril Raffaelli) teamed up with reformed vigilante Leito (David Belle) to save the notorious District 13, a racially charged ghetto populated by violent drug dealing gangs and vicious killers. Despite government promises to maintain order, the state of the district has deteriorated and is causing civil unrest. A group of corrupt cops and elected officials conspire to cash in on the redevelopment of the district by proposing it's destruction under the nuclear air strike. (I like the other kinds too, BTW.)

But if you enjoy watching incredibly gifted athletes doing great stunts done in a very believable way, and don't mind preposterous plots, then these movies might tickle your fancy. Just being able to watch David Belle (said to be the founder of parkour/parcour) is worth the price in my opinion.

So remember, don't expect any Profound Commentary on the Human Condition (thank goodness). Don't get too hung up on the silliness or the stereotypes, that's part of the fun. Just relax and enjoy great escapist fun with a good companion or two. silly plots, but among the best action movies ever made {'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Guy Ferland', 'Christine Moore', 'John Polson', 'Ron Fortunato', 'Seith Mann', 'Jerry Levine', 'Larry Teng', 'Lucy Liu', 'Aaron Lipstadt', 'Andrew Bernstein'], 'Studio': ['CBS']} If you're a fan of the Sherlock Holmes stories, and don't object to a well-done transformation of the theme, then you are likely to really enjoy this series. The acting is superb, the stories are compelling, and the whole thing just reeks of excellence and attention to detail.

I've been a fan of the Holmes stories since I was a little boy, having read all of them multiple times, and have watched the various film versions over the years. I've enjoyed some of them: I'm not a big fan of the Basil Rathbone versions, and I quite disliked the Guy Ritchie/Robert Downey versions. I think that the recent re-imagining done in this series and in the British series (by Gatiss/Moffat, with Benedict Cumberbatch & Martin Freeman) are excellent, and hugely enjoyable if you're not offended by the variation from the canonical texts. Very good revised version of Holmes & Watson {'Content advisory': ['Violence', 'alcohol use', 'smoking', 'foul language', 'sexual content'], 'Audio languages': ['English', 'English [Audio Description]'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Attenborough', 'Richard'], 'Producers': ['Richard Attenborough'], 'Starring': ['Ben Kingsley', 'Candice Bergen', 'Edward Fox'], 'Studio': ['Classics']} Gandhi was human, and had his weaknesses. But you wouldn't know it from this movie, this is about Gandhi the soon-to-revered, and presents him as someone just barely short of being a god. I would have preferred him presented as a great man, with all his compassion and leadership and steadfastness, but also with some human weaknesses.

Further, although I don't want to go into the history in a brief review (there are many authoritative sources for those who might be interested), but the portrayal of events, and of the other important players, is a bit too slick and shallow. It does great disservice to a worldwide audience that is unlikely to hear another version of the story. A bit too much worship. {'Content advisory': ['Violence', 'substance use', 'alcohol use', 'smoking', 'foul language'], 'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Michael Owen Morris', 'Robert Chetwyn', 'Martyn Friend', 'Ronald Wilson', 'Ken Hannam', 'Christopher Hodson', 'Robert Tronson'], 'Producers': ['Ken Riddington', 'Jonathan Alwyn'], 'Studio': ['BBC']} I read all the Allingham books & stories many years ago, and enjoyed them greatly.
